question: Which statement best describes the relationship between in-app Gemini in Google Workspace and the standalone Gemini experience?
answers: In Workspace, Gemini is built into apps like Gmail and Docs and respects org data and permissions; the standalone Gemini is separate and doesn’t automatically read your Workspace content.
Both versions are embedded in Workspace apps and, by default, have full access to all Workspace files and emails, with the standalone adding general-purpose chat.
Gemini appears in Workspace only through a Chrome extension that overlays features, while the standalone app is the primary way to use it with work data.
In Workspace, Gemini is provided as individual Marketplace add-ons you install per app, and these add-ons mirror the consumer Gemini’s default data access.
correct: In Workspace, Gemini is built into apps like Gmail and Docs and respects org data and permissions; the standalone Gemini is separate and doesn’t automatically read your Workspace content.

question: You need AI to synthesize information from Gmail, Drive, and Docs without manual uploads and with default respect for your organization’s permissions. Assume you cannot change admin settings today. Which statement best describes the right approach and why?
answers: Use Gemini in Workspace; it has built-in, permissions-aware access to Gmail, Drive, and Docs, enabling synthesis by default. Standalone Gemini does not have Workspace content access by default.

Use standalone Gemini with Deep Research; it automatically reads Gmail, Drive, and Docs without any admin configuration while still honoring your org’s permissions, making it the quickest way to synthesize across sources.
Use Workspace Studio to build a flow; Studio ships with full read access to Gmail and Drive by default, so it can aggregate content without additional setup or permission changes.
Either mode works; once you’re signed into your account, both Gemini in Workspace and standalone Gemini access the same Gmail/Drive/Docs content automatically under the same permissions.
correct: Use Gemini in Workspace; it has built-in, permissions-aware access to Gmail, Drive, and Docs, enabling synthesis by default. Standalone Gemini does not have Workspace content access by default.
